Isoprene was detected in 5 of 6 samples taken in the ambient air of Rio Blanco County, CO on July 24 and 25, 1978 at concentrations ranging from 0.1-5.6 ppb(2). Isoprene has been detected at concentrations of 4.2, 3.5, 5.7, 4.9, 0.7 and 3.6 ppb in 7 of 9 samples taken from the Smokey Mountains in Tennessee on September 25 and 26, 1978(2). Isoprene has been detected at concentrations of 1.2 and 0.4 ppb in the ambient air above Jones State Forest north of Houston, TX in January 1978(3). The average daily outdoor concentration for isoprene was reported as 0.608 ppb(4). Isoprene has been detected at concentrations ranging from 0.1-13.4 ppb in air samples taken from six locations in northwestern North Carolina from September 1981 to October 1982(5). In a 1-month field study examining ambient gaseous hydrocarbons in the mountains of the Georgian Republic of the USSR in July 1979, isoprene was detected at 7-30 ppb(6). Isoprene was detected in the Balbina forest, Amazonia in samples taken March and April 1998 at concentrations of 2-10 ppb(7). Isoprene was found in Taenikon, Switzerland throughout 1997 at concentrations of 0.1-0.15 ppb, 0-0.1 ppb are believed to be from biogenic sources(8). Samples taken July 6-8, 2000 in Tapajos, Brazil had maximum concentrations of isoprene of 5 ppb(9). Isoprene was detected in 21, 24, and 11% of the total biogenic emissions in Valley, Middle, and Peak Stations, in samples taken in Achenkirch, Tyrol, Austria, June 14, 1996(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: Isoprene has been identified as a constituent of tobacco, tobacco smoke, and tobacco substitute smoke(1). Environmental tobacco smoke was analyzed after smoking of research cigarettes by a machine in an experimental chamber 13.6 cu m in volume. The ventilation rate was 3.55 air changes per hr. Air removed for sampling added about 0.5 air changes per hr. One cigarette was lit every 30 min and was smoked with a 35 ml puff of 2 sec every minute until extinguished after about 12 min. Mainstream smoke was vented to the outside of the chamber. Additional tests were performed with one cigarette smoked every 15 min and with several commercial cigarette brands. Isoprene (ug/cu m) was detected in air samples at the following levels: 2 to 11, background; 128, grab samples at peak concentration with smoking 1 cigarette every 30 min; 92, continuous sampling with smoking 1 cigarette every 15 min; 225, continuous sampling with smoking 1 cigarette every 20 min. The average airborne yield for isoprene from cigarette smoke has been estimated to be 3,100 ug/cigarette. Concentration of isoprene using commercial brands of cigarettes in the chamber and in a tavern setting were similar to those produced by the research cigarettes(2). Isoprene was detected in tobacco smoke at a concentration of 360 ug/cu m(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Isoprene was found to be the main endogenous hydrocarbon of human breath(1-4), accounting for up to 70% of exhaled hydrocarbons(2). Isoprene concentrations in exhaled breath, measured in thirty volunteers (19 males, 11 females), ranged from 0 to 474 ppb with an average of 118 ppb(3). Isoprene was detected in expired breath during exercise with concentrations ranging from 5 to 400 ppb; concentrations decreased with time during exercise and older subjects had higher levels of isoprene compared to the younger subjects(4). Isoprene has been measured in human blood at concentrations between 15 and 70 nmol/liter (mean value of 37 +/- 25 (SD) nmol/L)(5).

Reference: (1) Pellizzari ED et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 28: 322-8 (1982)
(2) Wallace LA et al; Environ Res 35: 293-319 (1984)
(3) Conkle JP et al; Arch Environ Health 30: 290-5 (1975)
(4) Krotoszynski BK et al; J Anal Tox 3: 225-34 (1979)
(5) Krotoszynski B et al; J Chromat Sci 15: 239-44 (1977)
(6) Barrefors G et al; Environ Technol 17: 643-47 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: In a pilot study of pollutants in the milk of women living in 4 urban industrial areas in the USA, isoprene was detected in 1 of 8 samples(1). In a pilot study of volatile organic compounds in the exhaled breath of volunteers from Bayonne and Elizabeth, NJ and Research Triangle Park, NC, isoprene was detected in 1 of 12 samples(2). Isoprene has been detected in the expired air from 7 of 8 volunteers (including 2 smokers) during a test period of approximately 1 hr at quantities ranging from 15-390.0 ug(3). In a pilot study of volatile organic compounds in the exhaled breath of 54 nonsmoking volunteers, isoprene has been detected in 18 of 387 samples at concentrations ranging from 0.5-0.9 ng/L(4). Isoprene has been detected at concentrations ranging from approximately 18-60 ng/L in expired air in samples taken from 28 volunteers(5). Isoprene was identified, not quantified, in the expired breath of passengers on diesel buses in Sweden(6).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
